articles.author: Liam Johnston
articles.description:
The :has() pseudo-class is, hands-down, my favorite new CSS feature. I know it is for many of you as well, at least those of you who took the State of CSS survey. The ability to write selectors upside down …
More Real-World Uses for :has() originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: More Real-World Uses for :has()

articles.description:

articles.description:

articles.title: Solved With :has(): Vertical Spacing in Long-Form Text

articles.description:

articles.description:

:has is an unforgiving selector originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: Anders Pedersen
articles.description:
The good ol’ <table> tag is the most semantic HTML for showing tabular data. But I find it very hard to control how the table is presented, particularly column widths in a dynamic environment where you might not know how …

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
You know, this is the time of year where Chris normally publishes a big ol’ reflection of the past year. The first one was published in 2007, the same year CSS-Tricks began, and it continued all the way through 2021…

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Yuschick)
articles.description: In this article, Daniel Yuschick demonstrates that building selfish components is the key approach to avoiding different pitfalls on the way to good component design.
articles.title: The Key To Good Component Design Is Selfishness

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Pratik Joglekar)
articles.description: In this article, Pratik Joglekar explores the typical traits of introverts and uses them to make parallels and categorize digital experiences that can stand out without being loud.
articles.title: Introverted Design: Building Better UX Experiences

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Get better at your craft and support the people in Ukraine — that’s the idea behind our Figma Auto Layout Masterclass with Christine Vallaure. **We are donating all proceeds** from the online workshop to humanitarian aid in Ukraine. Monday, March 27, 09:00AM – 12:00PM PT / 18:00 – 21:00 CET. Donate and join!
articles.title: Figma Auto Layout Masterclass: An Online Workshop To Support Ukraine 🇺🇦

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Writing code documentation can be overwhelming when there’s no smooth process in place. Streamlining best practices and setting automation in your favor works a long way toward getting permanently up-to-date content that reflects the important pieces of your codebase.
articles.title: Code Documentation, Streamlined

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eloïse Martin)
articles.description: Largest Contentful Paint (or LCP) is a major web performance KPI which is still a new concept for many web developers since it became a ranking factor just recently. In this article, Eloïse Martin provides an overview of the best practices for the integration and optimization of an LCP image.
articles.title: Optimizing The Image Element LCP

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Louis Lazaris)
articles.description: Useful front-end tools for CSS and JavaScript developers that were most popular last year and will help you speed up your development workflow. Let’s dive in!
articles.title: Top Front-End Tools Of 2022

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Captioning can be much more than text. Design patterns for better UX of subtitles, captions, video players, transcripts and on-screen text.
articles.title: Closed Captions And Subtitles UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Shane Hudson)
articles.description: Recently UXPin has extended its powerful Merge technology by adding npm integration, allowing designers to sync React component libraries without requiring any developer input. This new step aims to improve collaboration between designers and developers.
articles.title: Making Your Collaboration Problems Go Away By Sharing Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eric Burel)
articles.description: This article is Eric Burel’s attempt at making the implementation of authentication less obscure. You’ll learn about tokens, authorization, CORS, credentials, HTTP headers, and such.
articles.title: Understanding Authentication In Websites: A Banking Analogy

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sara Dholakia)
articles.description: In this article, Sara Dholakia presents a guide on how to choose just the right type of data visualization, with guidelines and things to keep in mind.
articles.title: A Guide To Getting Data Visualization Right

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: That’s how people behave on the web in 2023. Some observations from real usability testing on what people do and what they don’t do on the web. From disabled copy-paste to magic link sign-in.
articles.title: The State Of Usability In 2023 🎊

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s start into the new year with a little inspiration boost: wallpapers created with love by the community for the community. Happy 2023!
articles.title: Opening The Doors To 2023 (January Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ruslan Yevych)
articles.description: In this article, Ruslan Yevych will show you an easy way how to predict the appearance of a problem known as WCAG Failure Under 1.4.4 Resize Text (AA) while zooming the page. You will have a clear understanding of the possible risks of using responsive typography at the stage of development.
articles.title: Fluid Typography: Predicting A Problem With Your User’s Zoom-In

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Alvin Bryan)
articles.description: No more random scripts in Python and JavaScript to transform CSV or JSON data. In this article, Alvin Bryan shows you how to use Miller, a small and powerful CLI tool, to do all your data processing.
articles.title: A Guide To Command-Line Data Manipulation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Nicolas Hoffmann)
articles.description: You may have already heard of CSS logical properties or RTL adaptations but are still deciding whether to deploy them widely. To help raise your awareness of their possibilities, Nicolas Hoffmann shares his experience of how he and his team at Proton carried out a massive move from CSS logical props to production and how you can consider them from a different perspective in your very own projects.
articles.title: Deploying CSS Logical Properties On Web Apps

articles.author: Joel Olawanle
articles.description: When building applications and websites on the internet, you’ll sometimes need your users to supply information by filling out a form. But then you might wonder – how do you get this data from the form? Well, you can do this with JavaScript. In this article, you will learn how
articles.title: How to Submit a Form with JavaScript – JS Submit Button Example

articles.author: Md. Fahim Bin Amin

articles.title: How to Write And Run C and C++ Code in Visual Studio Code

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: In Python, there are times when you might want to remove unnecessary characters from a string. Python provides two built-in methods you can use for that purpose – replace() and translate(). So, in this article, you will learn how to remove a character from a string with those two methods
articles.title: Remove From String in Python – How to Remove Characters from a String

articles.description: APIs, or application program interfaces, are essential mechanisms for businesses in all industries. articles.title: React Native Networking – How To Perform API Requests In React Native using the FetchAPI

JavaScript is a high-level, interpreted language used on the client side, meaning it runs in
articles.title: How Functions Work in JavaScript – JS Function Code Examples

articles.author: Eamonn Cottrell
articles.description: Without clean data, your spreadsheet is knocking on death's door. In this tutorial I will show you two fast ways to clean up the data in your Excel or Google Sheets spreadsheet. When dealing with data sets, especially large ones and/or those that you didn't create, it is likely that
articles.title: Excel Tutorial – How to Clean Data with the TRIM() and CLEAN() Functions

articles.title: How to Use Spell Check on your Linux Terminal

articles.description: Are you looking for a reliable and secure WordPress hosting provider? With so many options available, it can be hard to know which host is right for your needs. When selecting a hosting provider, several factors need to be taken into consideration. From the size of your website to the
articles.title: How to Choose a WordPress Host

articles.author: Saurabh Dashora
articles.description: Speed and performance are two of the key ingredients that make a website stand out from its peers. articles.title: What is Pre-Caching? How to Increase Website Speed and Performance

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: A list is a mutable sequence of elements surrounded by square brackets. If you’re familiar with JavaScript, a Python list is like a JavaScript array.
